audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker introducing the discussion of a reaction that uses less dry chlorine and shorter chlorination time, which he considers a plus, but requires hexamine. He believes hexamine may be "quite exotic reagent" in the US. He continues by describing having bought hexamine tablets, specifying that they are found in "army shops or some survival stuff." The speaker expresses uncertainty about army shops being prevalent in the US. He admits to not doing proper research before the reaction and later discovering the presence of trioxane in the tablets.

The clip features a single speaker, presumably male, discussing hexamine data, its solubility in acetone, and trioxane, delivered in a somewhat technical and informative tone. He details his process of dissolving tablets in water, mentioning a hot plate, stirrer bar, and the resulting solution, and notes that there was 'junk' in the tablets. The speaker then mentions adding 75 milliliters of benzol chloride to the hexamine solution.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker providing instructions and saying "then start stirring and reflux for a few hours." He then describes the process, stating, "Nothing really happened initially, but as the water started to reach boiling point, it started to go a little bit crazy." He concludes that it wasn't anything terrible, just looked a little more vigorous. Background sounds of bubbling or liquid movement are present throughout this description.

The audio begins with someone stating that after things "calmed down a little bit" you could see distinct layers, and that the aqueous layer went from "milky color to clear" over 40 minutes. They note that nothing exciting happened at first, but upon returning to the reaction, the organic layer looked red and the aqueous layer started looking milky again. There are some crystals in the condenser that they believe is hexamine, because the thing erupted initially. All speech is delivered by one speaker in a conversational and descriptive tone. Simultaneously, sounds resembling running water are audible, creating a sense of background ambience.

The audio features one male speaker discussing separating the organic layer, mentioning that it's unnecessary but needed to neutralize amines and hydrolyze benzal chlorides. His tone is informative and matter-of-fact. The background contains consistent bubbling sounds, likely from a chemical process, indicating a laboratory setting.

One male speaker describes an organic layer that mostly contains benzaldehyde. He suspects it also contains methylamine and benzal chloride. He suggests adding hydrochloric acid to form salt with the methylamine to be washed away with water. He then suggests using the hydrochloric acid to hydrolyze the benzal chloride.

A male speaker details the addition of hydrochloric acid. He observes that the amines are reacting, resulting in thick fog. Next, he notes that he will distill the benzaldehyde immediately, before performing the hydrolysis separately, as he expects to obtain a clear, non-yellow product by doing so.

Following a distillation, a man speaks, noting a loss of a third of the product, about 25 milliliters, but considers it acceptable given a four-hour reflux in atmospheric conditions and observed color changes. He then describes the processed look of the product after four hours, expressing hope that the distillation has removed impurities. He then describes the separating the organic layer and adding water to neutralize hydrochloric acid, opting for calcium carbonate due to the unavailability of alternatives, albeit with a belief it would work. He finishes with describing distilling benzaldehyde.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker detailing a distillation process and sample analysis, mentioning the results indicated a spicy taste and smell with the presence of benzaldehyde and an overwhelming impurity that is difficult to remove.

A male speaker describes separating benzaldehyde, noting that the amount is less than initially. He mentions drying it with calcium sulfate and regretting not drying the bottle first. Finally, he states that he obtained about 18 milliliters of benzaldehyde.

The audio clip features a single male speaker. He begins by stating "Now that doesn't mean that this method sucks". He continues by clarifying he did something on purpose, "just to see if I can get rid of the impurity that I saw in the sample," and expressing disappointment, saying, "and unfortunately I can't." The tone is analytical, shifting from somewhat defensive to slightly frustrated. A brief, isolated sound follows the speech.

A single male speaker discusses an experiment, stating "I put the benzaldehyde sample in the freezer just to see if something will crystallize out". He notes the presence of crystals at -25 degrees Celsius, ruling out benzoic acid and benzoyl chloride. He remarks that even after filtering the crystals, the benzaldehyde smell was "really just awful". The general tone is curious and scientific.

A single male speaker with an inquisitive tone describes a chemical process they conducted, mentioning freezing, filtering, and the presence of crystals in benzaldehyde. They note the absence of liquid and an ambient temperature of about 10 degrees Celsius, remarking on the "quite impressive" oxidation rate.

The audio clip starts with a single male speaker explaining his attempt at vacuum distillation to remove an impurity, and his disappointment that it failed. His tone is slightly frustrated but also resigned, acknowledging the possibility of future success. The speaker proceeds to preview the current state of his process with a video presentation. He wraps up by signaling the end of his update, saying "see you later" in a slightly deflated tone.
